FinScript
Table of Contents

Namespace FinSysPlatform.Domain.Market.Representers

Classes

BarTimeRepresenter

Formatter for DateTime value which stores a time of bar Bar Using this formatter in model is better than using custom converters in XAML, because 1. With formatter XAML notation looks much shorter and simpler. Especially, if you refer to the model property from several XAMLs 2. It gives you strong-typed compile-time checking of binding 3. Representer may be context-driven (for example, it may use global settings of the app) in future

BaseQuantityRepresenterContainer<TRepresenter, TInnerValue>

Stores BaseQuantityRepresenter<TRepresenter, TInnerValue> inside and provides notification property Value that can refresh automatically on settings change

BaseQuantityRepresenter<TRepresenter, TInnerValue>

Base quantity representer

BaseQuantityRepresenter<TRepresenter, TInnerValue>.BaseQuantityObjectSerializer

Base object serializer for quantity representer

BaseQuantityRepresenter<TRepresenter, TInnerValue>.BaseQuantityTypeConverter

Type converter implementation

BaseQuantityRepresenter<TRepresenter, TInnerValue>.BaseQuantityTypeConverter.ParseResult

Parse context

DeferrableObservableCollectionWithQuantityRepresenterSupport<T>

An extended version of FinSysPlatform.NetExtension.Misc.SuspendableObservableCollection<T> which subscribes to Changed to propagate the Changed event to its children

FormattedPriceRepresenter

Representer for Price very similar to PriceRepresenter, but with two additional abilities:

  1. Cutting trailing zeroes
  2. Cutting digits before decimal point (like 12345.6 -> "..345.6")
IMoneyRepresenterExtensions

Extension methods for IMoneyRepresenter

InstrumentRepresenter

The formatter for Instrument. This class is commonly used to bind XAML views to property of Instrument with predefined formatting settings Using this class you should not care about how the instrument really must look and should not use any converters for it Using the formatter in model is better than using custom converters in XAML, because 1. With formatter XAML notation looks much shorter and simpler. Especially, if you refer to the model property from several XAMLs 2. It gives you strong-typed compile-time checking of binding 3. Representer may be context-driven (for example, it may use global settings of the app) in future

LargeNumberRepresenter

Representer for any number of double type

ListWithQuantityRepresenterSupport<T>

An extended version of ObservableCollection<T> which subscribes to Changed to propagate the Changed event to its children

MarketPositionRepresenter

The formatter for MarketPosition. This class is commonly used to bind XAML views to property of MarketPosition with predefined formatting settings Using this class you should not care about how the trade action title really must look and should not use any converters for it Using the formatter in model is better than using custom converters in XAML, because 1. With formatter XAML notation looks much shorter and simpler. Especially, if you refer to the model property from several XAMLs 2. It gives you strong-typed compile-time checking of binding 3. Representer may be context-driven (for example, it may use global settings of the app) in future

MarketPricesRepresenter

PriceAndSpanRepresenter

Represents the current price (FinSysPlatform.Domain.Market.Representers.PriceAndSpanRepresenter.CurrentPrice) and price delta (DeltaInPoints)

PriceRepresenter

The price formatter for specific Instrument. This class is commonly used to bind XAML views to properties which store prices of specific Instrument with predefined formatting settings Using this class you should not care about how the instrument really must look and should not use any converters for it Using the formatter in model is better than using custom converters in XAML, because 1. With formatter XAML notation looks much shorter and simpler. Especially, if you refer to the model property from several XAMLs 2. It gives you strong-typed compile-time checking of binding 3. Representer may be context-driven (for example, it may use global settings of the app) in future

TradeTimeRepresenter

With formatter XAML notation looks much shorter and simpler. Especially, if you refer to the model property from several XAMLs 2. It gives you strong-typed compile-time checking of binding 3. Representer may be context-driven (for example, it may use global settings of the app) in future

Structs

LightweightMoneyRepresenter

For optimization purposes: unlike standard MoneyRepresenter this one consumes as little memory as it is possible at all First of all, this is a struct. Struct is stored by value, which means that you will save extra 8 bytes (for x64) no having a reference to it. Also, struct has no inheritance, VM table and other things which also saves some bytes. Then, it has only 2 essential fields: Money and FormatCulture. Anything other settings are removed and default settings are used For x64 application storing of one instance of MoneyRepresenter needs in average 48 bytes (8 bytes of reference included) whereas LightweightMoneyRepresenter needs only 16 bytes TODO Support IComparable for proper sorting and grouping in grids

LightweightSignedQuantityRepresenter

For optimization purposes: unlike standard SignedQuantityRepresenter this one consumes as little memory as it is possible at all First of all, this is a struct with packed fields. Struct is stored by value, which means that you will save extra 8 bytes (for x64) no having a reference to it. Also, struct has no inheritance, VM table and other things which also saves some bytes. For x64 application storing of one instance of SignedQuantityRepresenter needs in average 40 bytes (8 bytes of reference included) whereas LightweightSignedQuantityRepresenter needs only 9 bytes TODO Support IEquatable, IComparable for proper sorting and grouping in grids

Interfaces

IMoneyRepresenter

A common interface for both money representers LightweightMoneyRepresenter, MoneyRepresenter

IQuantityRepresenter

Basic functionality of any quantity representer

IQuantityRepresenterFormatSettingsChangeEventHandler

The interface to handle Changed change event via forwarding Usually, some parent handles the event and forwards it to its children if the children support this interface

ISignedQuantityRepresenter

Basic functionality of any quantity representer
